key_points: Tucson officer to be fired for fatally shooting Richard Lee Richards, a 61-year-old man in a motorized wheelchair, 9 times from behind.
The incident occurred after Richards was suspected of shoplifting a toolbox from Walmart and allegedly pulled a knife on an employee.
Officer Ryan Remington, who has been with the Tucson police department for four years, was the officer who shot Richards.
The shooting took place as Richards was entering a Lowe's store, with surveillance and body camera footage capturing the event.
Before the shooting, Remington, working off-duty as Walmart security, followed Richards and called for backup.
The Pima County Attorney's Office is reviewing the fatal shooting for possible criminal charges against Remington.
Tucson police chief Chris Magnus condemned Remington's actions as a violation of department policy and training in use of force.
Remington's attorney claimed he had no nonlethal options due to the placement of the wheelchair.
Tucson Mayor Regina Romero called the actions "unconscionable and indefensible" and supports the investigation.
The incident follows another investigation involving an off-duty officer in Tucson.
